conclusion: Understanding the properties of an ideal gas under different thermodynamic processes.
The P-V diagram shows four points (a, b, c, d) connected by lines representing different thermodynamic processes.
Definition of isochoric and adiabatic processes.
The line connecting point b to point d represents an isochoric process.
The line connecting point c to point a represents an adiabatic process.
Internal energy of an ideal gas depends only on temperature.
In an adiabatic process, PV^Î³ = constant.
Temperature changes along the adiabatic path from c to a.
At point c, the gas is at a high pressure and low volume.
At point a, the gas is at a lower pressure and higher volume.
Temperature at point a is lower than at point c due to adiabatic expansion.
Internal energy at state a is less than at state c.
The internal energy at state a is less than the internal energy at state c.
